Award.AwardTitle: RUI-Benzannulated antiaromatic dications and dianions: using antiaromaticity to probe delocalization
Award.AbstractNarration:
Through this award, funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms-B Program of the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Nancy Mills of Trinity University will examine the factors that affect delocalization by modification of antiaromatic dications and dianions. Antiaromatic species have been shown to be more sensitive to factors affecting delocalization because of their inherent tendency to avoid delocalization which results in an increase in antiaromaticity. For example, by annulation of a variety of polycyclic aromatic compounds to a cyclopentadienyl cation, the tension between the energetic advantages of delocalization of positive charge versus the stability from the intact polycyclic aromatic compound can be probed. Antiaromatic dianions are also accessible experimentally. Initial studies suggest that they are more antiaromatic than corresponding dications. Varying the position of benzannulation of a cycloheptatrienyl anionic system can again result in differences in antiaromaticity through differences in patterns of delocalization.

Stability is one of the most important concepts in chemistry because all chemical reactions result in making the most stable molecules possible. There is a class of compounds, called antiaromatic, which have been suggested by theory to be particularly unstable. Needless to say, these compounds have not been carefully studied because of the anticipated difficulty in making them. However, a suite of these compounds was discovered in an attempt to make something else and have proven to be much easier to make and study than anticipated. Because they are still relatively unstable, they turn out to be very sensitive to changes in their structure. Just as some changes in a physical structure, like a house or an automobile, might be hard to see in the dim light of dusk, but be very visible in daylight, changes that are hard to understand in a molecular structure that is stable, become very visible in a less stable, antiaromatic compound. These studies will be carried out by undergraduate students, with an emphasis on students just beginning their study of chemistry. By engaging these students in research early in their academic career, they are in a better position to learn what aspects of science interest them the most, and to make choices in coursework to support that interest. They will be aided by post-doctoral researchers who are interested in teaching undergraduate students as a career. The workforce development inherent in training undergraduates and prospective faculty is the primary broader impact of the grant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding what makes something stable is crucial in deciding what compounds are possible to make and in understanding how they behave. In organic chemistry, one of the key theories that explains stability is called aromaticity, because the original compounds that were studied included spices that were aromatic. The rationale for the stability of these compounds included a prediction that other types of compounds, called antiaromatic, were particularly unstable. For obvious reasons, scientists were not excited about trying to make antiaromatic compounds, because they feared that the compounds would be too unstable to be formed. We discovered a set of charged compounds that were antiaromatic but, because of their charge, were stable enough to be studied. The ability to compare the experimental behavior of these species with calculations of their properties gave validation to the calculations and allowed them to be used to understand more antiaromatic compounds that couldn't be synthesized.  Prior to our work,  the majority of reports about antiaromatic species involved computational work rather than experimental.  With the preparation of our antiaromatic dications and dianions and the measurement of their properties, chemists were able to check the results of computational examinations of antiaromaticity and evaluate their effectiveness. The interplay between theory and experiment is critical to the advancement of science and our antiaromatic species provided the opportunity for this interplay.

            Although the original interest in antiaromaticity was to determine whether the theory suggesting its existence was correct, antiaromatic compounds have interesting properties in their own right. For example, most organic (carbon-containing) compounds have electrons that exist in pairs, but antiaromatic species have unpaired electrons, like metals. One of the strengths of organic chemistry comes from the ability to design molecules with particular properties, like polymers. It might be possible to create an antiaromatic molecule that behaves like a metal, but is liquid at room temperature. There is only one liquid metallic element, mercury, but this might open the door to a multitude of liquid metals. When we began our study of antiaromaticity, there were very few antiaromatic compounds that had been prepared; now there are hundreds, because we, and others, have shown that they are worth seeking because they are more accessible than originally assumed.

            This work was done at Trinity University, primarily with undergraduate collaborators, often students who had completed only one year of college chemistry. Student involvement in research, particularly early on in their academic careers, is one of the most effective means of education in science. Because the answers to the questions being asked are not known, in comparison with experiments in teaching laboratories, students must be much more concerned with the quality of their work, including control experiments to assure that their data is reliable. Oftentimes, the outcomes of the experiments are unexpected and they, and their research director must determine if an error was made during the experiment or if the basic understanding of the chemistry was incorrect, and then construct experiments to test the new thesis. Studies, particularly by David Lopatto of Grinnell College, have shown that undergraduate research is one of the most effective means to develop the intellectual maturity that is the outcome of a college education and the foundation of life-long learning.
